posts.title: Markdown Cheat Sheet
posts.markdown:

posts.title: Ionic - Side Menu Navigation App
posts.markdown:
I wanted to build an app with Ionic & Phonegap that had a side menu navigation. Unfortunately the [example on the Ionic site](http://ionicframework.com/examples/side-menu/) was very basic and didn't include any routing. I decided to extend upon the basic side menu app adding in a navigation controller as well as a dynamic menu. You can view the source on my [github](https://github.com/georgiknox/ionic-side-menu-with-navigation). controller.js ``` var sideMenuApp = angular.module('sideMenuApp', ['ionic', 'ngRoute', 'sideMenuApp.controllers', 'sideMenuApp.services']); sideMenuApp.config(function ($compileProvider) { $compileProvider.aHrefSanitizationWhitelist(/^\s*(https?|ftp|mailto|file|tel):/); }) sideMenuApp.config(['$routeProvider', function ($routeProvider, $locationProvider) { $routeProvider .when('/one', { controller: 'OneController', templateUrl: 'templates/one.html' }) .when('/two', { controller: 'TwoController', templateUrl: 'templates/two.html' }) .when('/three', { controller: 'ThreeController', templateUrl: 'templates/three.html' }) .otherwise({ redirectTo: '/one' }); }]); ``` index.html ```

Slide Me

Menu

    {{item.text}}
```
posts.html:
I wanted to build an app with Ionic & Phonegap that had a side menu navigation. Unfortunately the example on the Ionic site was very basic and didn't include any routing.

I decided to extend upon the basic side menu app adding in a navigation controller as well as a dynamic menu. You can view the source on my github.

controller.js 

var sideMenuApp = angular.module('sideMenuApp', ['ionic', 'ngRoute', 'sideMenuApp.controllers', 'sideMenuApp.services']);

sideMenuApp.config(function ($compileProvider) {  
    $compileProvider.aHrefSanitizationWhitelist(/^\s*(https?|ftp|mailto|file|tel):/);
})

sideMenuApp.config(['$routeProvider', function ($routeProvider, $locationProvider) {  
    $routeProvider
        .when('/one', {
            controller: 'OneController',
            templateUrl: 'templates/one.html'
        })
        .when('/two', {
            controller: 'TwoController',
            templateUrl: 'templates/two.html'
        })
        .when('/three', {
            controller: 'ThreeController',
            templateUrl: 'templates/three.html'
        })
        .otherwise({ redirectTo: '/one' });
}]);

index.html 

<div ng-controller="MenuController">  
    <side-menus>

        <!-- Center content -->
        <pane side-menu-content nav-router>
            <header class="bar bar-header bar-assertive">
                <button class="button button-icon" ng-click="toggleLeft()"><i class="icon ion-navicon"></i></button>
                <h1 class="title">Slide Me</h1>
            </header>
            <!-- where the content of each page will be rendered -->
            <ng-view></ng-view>
        </pane>

        <!-- Left Side Menu -->
        <side-menu side="left">
            <header class="bar bar-header bar-assertive">
                <h1 class="title">Menu</h1>
            </header>
            <content has-header="true">
                <ul class="list" ng-click="toggleLeft()">
                    <a href="{{item.link}}" class="item item-icon-left" ng-repeat="item in list">
                        <i ng-class="item.iconClass"></i>
                        {{item.text}}
                    </a>
                </ul>
            </content>
        </side-menu>
    </side-menus>
</div>

posts.title: Git Alias Setup
posts.markdown:
Who's got time to write out long words like "status" and "commit". 
Cheat with some alias'.

Update your ~/.gitconfig file by performing the following:

```bash
$ git config --global alias.st status 
$ git config --global alias.ci 'commit -v'
```
posts.html:
Who's got time to write out long words like "status" and "commit".
Cheat with some alias'.

Update your ~/.gitconfig file by performing the following:

$ git config --global alias.st status 
$ git config --global alias.ci 'commit -v'

posts.title: Quick and dirty HTTP servers for devlopement
posts.markdown:
Recently I've been getting into creating phonegap apps. These all come with a www folder which contains all the static web files. I wanted to run my app in a browser instead of always deploying to the emulator.

Let's look at a few command line options:
1. Node: http-server
2. Python: SimpleHttpServer

### Node Command Line HTTP Server
Ensure that you have node and npm installed. We will then install a [simple HTTP server](https://github.com/nodeapps/http-server)

```
$ npm install http-server -g
```

to run from www:
```
$ http-server www
```

### Python HTTP Server
Ensure you have python installed and then simply change into the www (or equivalent) folder and run

```
$ python -m SimpleHTTPServer
```

#### Add an alias to your profile
I found myself running this command so often I created an alias. Open up ```~/.profile``` and add the following line.
```
alias pyserv="python -m SimpleHTTPServer"
```

You can now run the server with:
```bash
$ pyserv
```
posts.html:
Recently I've been getting into creating phonegap apps. These all come with a www folder which contains all the static web files. I wanted to run my app in a browser instead of always deploying to the emulator.

Let's look at a few command line options:
1. Node: http-server
2. Python: SimpleHttpServer

Node Command Line HTTP Server

Ensure that you have node and npm installed. We will then install a simple HTTP server

$ npm install http-server -g

to run from www: 

$ http-server www

Python HTTP Server

Ensure you have python installed and then simply change into the www (or equivalent) folder and run

$ python -m SimpleHTTPServer

Add an alias to your profile

I found myself running this command so often I created an alias. Open up ~/.profile and add the following line. 

alias pyserv="python -m SimpleHTTPServer"

You can now run the server with: 

$ pyserv

posts.title: Heroku + GitHub - Pushing to multiple git repo's
posts.markdown:
Deploying and open source [GitHub](github.com) project to [Heroku](heroku.com) is probably a common development workflow. 

If you already have a github project setup, simply run these commands:

```
$ heroku apps:create example
$ git remote add heroku <heroku repo>
```

Then to push
```
$ git push origin master -- push to github
$ git push heroku master -- push to heroku
```
posts.html:
Deploying and open source GitHub project to Heroku is probably a common development workflow.

If you already have a github project setup, simply run these commands:

$ heroku apps:create example
$ git remote add heroku <heroku repo>

Then to push 

$ git push origin master -- push to github
$ git push heroku master -- push to heroku

posts.title: Making bash profile changes available in current session
posts.markdown:
Today, I learnt another bash command to file away under useful. If you want to make the changes you just made to your profile available in the current terminal session, simply change the `.profile` file and then run:

```
$ source ~/.profile
```
posts.html:
Today, I learnt another bash command to file away under useful. If you want to make the changes you just made to your profile available in the current terminal session, simply change the .profile file and then run:

$ source ~/.profile

posts.title: about me
posts.markdown: > I have been hand-crafting beautiful software for the past 7 years. > I run Girl Geek Sydney and am Co-Founder of Women Who Code Sydney I love to code and a spend good deal of my own time writing code for the fun of it. I have endless ideas for apps and not enough time to develop them all. I have an equal love for server-side and front-end coding. ### current coding love + Learning Scala + Learning Ruby + Rails + Creating apps with Angular JS + PhoneGap + Contributing to open-source projects Check out my GitHub to see what I'm currently crafting. ### professional me I've worked for many fabulous companies big and small and am currently a Senior Software Engineer @ RedBalloon coding in Java & Scala. Check out my LinkedIn page for more info. ###fun facts + I have two cats who like to sit on my keyboard whilst I try to type + I am trying to [learn German](https://www.duolingo.com/catrapture) + I love mac cheese + I am an avid Scuba Diver & Rock Climber + I travel to places that I can have adventures in
posts.html:
I have been hand-crafting beautiful software for the past 7 years.

I run Girl Geek Sydney and am Co-Founder of Women Who Code Sydney

I love to code and a spend good deal of my own time writing code for the fun of it. I have endless ideas for apps and not enough time to develop them all. I have an equal love for server-side and front-end coding.

current coding love

Check out my GitHub to see what I'm currently crafting.

professional me

Check out my LinkedIn page for more info.

fun facts

  • I have two cats who like to sit on my keyboard whilst I try to type
  • I am trying to learn German
  • I love mac cheese
  • I am an avid Scuba Diver & Rock Climber
  • I travel to places that I can have adventures in

posts.title: SheHacks - Hackathon
posts.markdown:
![](/content/images/2014/Jan/IMG_3506-1.jpg "GitHub attendees stickers")

Today I posted the details of [SheHacks](http://www.girlgeeksydney.com/she-hacks/) the first Hackathon event that Girl Geeks Sydney will be putting on. I'm kinda wondering if it will be the first all women's  hack event in Australia?  

> The idea that I could be in a room full of women programmers is so exciting! 

I'm curious to see how many attendee's we will get. In the past our Girl Geek Sydney events have sold over 100 tickets in a matter of hours. But this event is different... we are calling for programmers (mostly) as well as a few tickets for designers and non-technical people. We are aiming for 60 hackers. The idea that I could be in a room full of women programmers is so exciting!

It's been a huge task to undertake and I'll be really happy if the event goes well. Luckily, one thing did come easily and that was finding sponsorship for the event. Google were fantastic and jumped on board really quickly to sponsor the location and catering. Its a bit of a tricky event to sponsor as we need building access until quite late and its run over a weekend. Prize sponsorship is looking good too with Microsoft now locked in. Github are sponsoring cupcakes and stickers.

UPDATE - [Registrations now open](http://she-hacks.eventbrite.com.au/).

The idea that I could be in a room full of women programmers is so exciting!

I'm curious to see how many attendee's we will get. In the past our Girl Geek Sydney events have sold over 100 tickets in a matter of hours. But this event is different... we are calling for programmers (mostly) as well as a few tickets for designers and non-technical people. We are aiming for 60 hackers. The idea that I could be in a room full of women programmers is so exciting!

It's been a huge task to undertake and I'll be really happy if the event goes well. Luckily, one thing did come easily and that was finding sponsorship for the event. Google were fantastic and jumped on board really quickly to sponsor the location and catering. Its a bit of a tricky event to sponsor as we need building access until quite late and its run over a weekend. Prize sponsorship is looking good too with Microsoft now locked in. Github are sponsoring cupcakes and stickers.

UPDATE - Registrations now open.

posts.title: Common Git Commands
posts.markdown:
A collection of handy git commands

```
$ git checkout -b <localBranchName> origin/<branchName> (create new local branch from remote)
$ git push -u origin <branchName> (pushes a local branch to remote) 
$ git branch -d <localBranchName> (delete local branch)
$ git push origin --delete <branchName> (delete remote branch)

$ git reset HEAD <file> (unstage file)
$ git reset --soft HEAD^ (resets to the commit before local HEAD and puts changed files back to staging)
$ git reset --hard HEAD^ (resets to the commit before local HEAD and blows away changes)
$ git reset --hard origin/HEAD (reset to the HEAD of remote origin and blows away changes)
$ git checkout -- . (discard all changes in working directory)
$ git checkout -- /path/to/file (discard change to specific file in working directory)
$ git checkout /path/to/dir (override changes in directory)
$ git revert -m 1 SHA (reverted back a merge commit that has been committed to remote)

$ git commit --amend --no-edit (amend last edit but keep original commit message)

$ git branch -a (list all branches, including remote)
$ git ls-remote (list remotes)
$ git log --stat (verbose git log)
```
posts.html:
A collection of handy git commands

$ git checkout -b <localBranchName> origin/<branchName> (create new local branch from remote)
$ git push -u origin <branchName> (pushes a local branch to remote) 
$ git branch -d <localBranchName> (delete local branch)
$ git push origin --delete <branchName> (delete remote branch)

$ git reset HEAD <file> (unstage file)
$ git reset --soft HEAD^ (resets to the commit before local HEAD and puts changed files back to staging)
$ git reset --hard HEAD^ (resets to the commit before local HEAD and blows away changes)
$ git reset --hard origin/HEAD (reset to the HEAD of remote origin and blows away changes)
$ git checkout -- . (discard all changes in working directory)
$ git checkout -- /path/to/file (discard change to specific file in working directory)
$ git checkout /path/to/dir (override changes in directory)
$ git revert -m 1 SHA (reverted back a merge commit that has been committed to remote)

$ git commit --amend --no-edit (amend last edit but keep original commit message)

$ git branch -a (list all branches, including remote)
$ git ls-remote (list remotes)
$ git log --stat (verbose git log)

posts.title: Scala Newbie Lesson - Classes + Objects
posts.markdown:
![](http://basementcoders.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/newsflash_logo-e1290819421137.png)

I'll admit it, i'm one of those people who skip the instructions manual and prefer to figure it out as I go along. This works well... to a point.
I've been [writing some Scala lately](https://github.com/rowdyrabbit/eventapp), but really, i'm not quite sure what I'm doing, so its time to go back to basics and really try to understand the language properly.

##Scala newbie lesson 1 - Classes + Objects

###Hello World example 1

*hello.scala*
```
object HelloWorld extends App {
  println("Hello, World!")
}
```
**Tell me interesting things**

* Creates an application and output's `Hello, World!`
* Notice how the class name is different than the file name?
* Can have multiple classes per file
* the `extends App` bit just allows us to turn this basic object into an executable file. See the docs for more info. If you don't have the docs installed in your IDE I suggest you do so, it makes learning much easier.

**Compile & Run it**
Now, remember we are learning things from the ground up, so rather than let your IDE compile this, do it yourself with the following commands:
```
$ scalac hello.scala -- compiles the class
$ scala HelloWorld -- runs the 'app', can you tab completion after successful compile to bring up the `HelloWorld` option
```

###Hello World example 2

*helloAgain.scala*
```
object HelloWorld {
  def sayHi() {
    println("Hi!");
  }
}
```

**Compile & Run**
A bit different than last time...
```
$ scalac helloAgain.scala -- compiles the class
$ scala -- brings up scala console
$ HelloWorld.sayHi() -- looks suspiciously familiar, like a java static method call infact.
```

**Tell me interesting things**

* main method doesn't require a type as it doesn't return anything
* `object` means singleton class
* `sayHi` is an instance method
* `HelloWorld.sayHi()` is like calling a static method in java. Notice you don't need to instansiate the class with the new opeartor.
* the instance is created on demand when it is first used
* there are no static methods in Scala


###Resources
####Why learn Scala?
* [Scala Lang - About Scala](http://www.scala-lang.org/old/node/25)

####Getting Started
* [Scala Lang - Getting Started](http://www.scala-lang.org/documentation/getting-started.html)
* [Cousera](https://www.coursera.org/course/progfun) - Also good for Intermediate learners

####References
* [http://www.codecommit.com/blog/scala/scala-for-java-refugees-part-1](http://www.codecommit.com/blog/scala/scala-for-java-refugees-part-1)
posts.html:
I'll admit it, i'm one of those people who skip the instructions manual and prefer to figure it out as I go along. This works well... to a point.
I've been writing some Scala lately, but really, i'm not quite sure what I'm doing, so its time to go back to basics and really try to understand the language properly.

Scala newbie lesson 1 - Classes + Objects

Hello World example 1

hello.scala

object HelloWorld extends App {  
  println("Hello, World!")
}

Tell me interesting things

  • Creates an application and output's Hello, World!
  • Notice how the class name is different than the file name?
  • Can have multiple classes per file
  • the extends App bit just allows us to turn this basic object into an executable file. See the docs for more info. If you don't have the docs installed in your IDE I suggest you do so, it makes learning much easier.

Compile & Run it Now, remember we are learning things from the ground up, so rather than let your IDE compile this, do it yourself with the following commands: 

$ scalac hello.scala -- compiles the class
$ scala HelloWorld -- runs the 'app', can you tab completion after successful compile to bring up the `HelloWorld` option

Hello World example 2

helloAgain.scala

object HelloWorld {  
  def sayHi() {
    println("Hi!");
  }
}

Compile & Run A bit different than last time... 

$ scalac helloAgain.scala -- compiles the class
$ scala -- brings up scala console
$ HelloWorld.sayHi() -- looks suspiciously familiar, like a java static method call infact.

Tell me interesting things

  • main method doesn't require a type as it doesn't return anything
  • object means singleton class
  • sayHi is an instance method
  • HelloWorld.sayHi() is like calling a static method in java. Notice you don't need to instansiate the class with the new opeartor.
  • the instance is created on demand when it is first used
  • there are no static methods in Scala

Resources

Why learn Scala?

  • Scala Lang - About Scala

Getting Started

  • Scala Lang - Getting Started
  • Cousera - Also good for Intermediate learners

References

  • http://www.codecommit.com/blog/scala/scala-for-java-refugees-part-1

posts.title: Why we need women focussed technical groups
posts.markdown:
![](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-HkBhJtnEvmc/UCSE3ibWuPI/AAAAAAAAAV4/1bN48WTOSQc/w377-h249-n-k/ggd%2B10.jpg)
I'm one of the main organisers of [Girl Geek Sydney](www.girlgeeksydney.com) and was recently asked to be a Track Host for YOW! Sydney. I was pretty pumped because as I have been contracting for the last 3-4 years, I haven't splurged on conference tickets - so a free ticket to this software development conference sounded like a great deal. As part of being a Track Host I had to introduce 2 speakers, and was allowed to give a quick spiel about the technical group I represented. So as part of my presentation I introduced Girl Geek Sydney and that we were a networking group for women. Later, at the conference drinks, a guy came up and talked to me saying that he was offeneded that Girl Geeks excluded men. He wasn't aggressive or mean but seemed to be quite miffed that he couldn't attend. I have to admit, I was a little taken aback. I have been running Girl Geek Sydney for about 1.5years and hadn't ever heard any negative feedback from anyone. I said to him that the Girl Geek Dinner rules allow men to attend if they are invited by a woman and this was to ensure a max of 50/50 men to women ratio at any given event. So his comments made me think... should we continue to have women technical groups? > So his comments made me think... should we continue to have women technical groups? Now as I delve into this delicate topic of gender diversity let me just say right now that I'm not a talented writer, I mean I can write code, but writing sentences and words in a beautiful elequent way, is not a talent of mine. So if this doesn't come out right, i'm sorry... I personally feel that we still need women focussed techncial groups as sadly, there is just too damn few of us and we need a place to feel at home. > When I walk into most conferences and technical user groups I FEEL LIKE I DON'T BELONG. And the best way I can explain this feeling this is through my own raw personal experiences, so here it is... When I walk into most conferences and technical user groups I FEEL LIKE I DON'T BELONG. It's not that the guys aren't friendly, even though some of them do stare a bit too much.... It's because i'm generally one of a handful of other women. Even getting up the courage to attend a technical event is difficult. Often I won't got unless I go with one of my female programmer friends. Strength in solidarity and all that. In contrast, attending a Girl Geek Sydney event is a totally different affair. I can go on my own, I don't feel awkward... I feel like I belong. So what can we do to fix this? Well I think the first thing to do is encourage more women to attend technical user groups. One way to do this would be to cross promote tech groups. Eg GGD promotes SydJS. If women know there will be some other women from a group they already know in attendence, they might be more likely to come. In the meantime, I firmly believe there is a place for women focussed technical groups.
posts.html:
I'm one of the main organisers of Girl Geek Sydney and was recently asked to be a Track Host for YOW! Sydney. I was pretty pumped because as I have been contracting for the last 3-4 years, I haven't splurged on conference tickets - so a free ticket to this software development conference sounded like a great deal.

As part of being a Track Host I had to introduce 2 speakers, and was allowed to give a quick spiel about the technical group I represented. So as part of my presentation I introduced Girl Geek Sydney and that we were a networking group for women.

Later, at the conference drinks, a guy came up and talked to me saying that he was offeneded that Girl Geeks excluded men. He wasn't aggressive or mean but seemed to be quite miffed that he couldn't attend.

I have to admit, I was a little taken aback. I have been running Girl Geek Sydney for about 1.5years and hadn't ever heard any negative feedback from anyone.

I said to him that the Girl Geek Dinner rules allow men to attend if they are invited by a woman and this was to ensure a max of 50/50 men to women ratio at any given event. So his comments made me think... should we continue to have women technical groups?

So his comments made me think... should we continue to have women technical groups?

Now as I delve into this delicate topic of gender diversity let me just say right now that I'm not a talented writer, I mean I can write code, but writing sentences and words in a beautiful elequent way, is not a talent of mine. So if this doesn't come out right, i'm sorry...

I personally feel that we still need women focussed techncial groups as sadly, there is just too damn few of us and we need a place to feel at home.

When I walk into most conferences and technical user groups I FEEL LIKE I DON'T BELONG.

And the best way I can explain this feeling this is through my own raw personal experiences, so here it is... When I walk into most conferences and technical user groups I FEEL LIKE I DON'T BELONG. It's not that the guys aren't friendly, even though some of them do stare a bit too much.... It's because i'm generally one of a handful of other women. Even getting up the courage to attend a technical event is difficult. Often I won't got unless I go with one of my female programmer friends. Strength in solidarity and all that.

In contrast, attending a Girl Geek Sydney event is a totally different affair. I can go on my own, I don't feel awkward... I feel like I belong.

So what can we do to fix this?

Well I think the first thing to do is encourage more women to attend technical user groups. One way to do this would be to cross promote tech groups. Eg GGD promotes SydJS. If women know there will be some other women from a group they already know in attendence, they might be more likely to come.

In the meantime, I firmly believe there is a place for women focussed technical groups.

posts.title: She Hacks App Submitted to App Store
posts.markdown:
Pretty excited right now, like a little kid about to be handed a big ice-cream cone dipped in chocolate and dunked in sprinkles. You see we (me and my coding BFF [@rowdyrabbit](https://twitter.com/rowdyrabbit)) just submitted our very first app to the app store.

![](/content/images/2014/Jan/Screen_Shot_2014_01_29_at_9_24_41_PM-1.png)
![](/content/images/2014/Jan/Screen_Shot_2014_01_29_at_9_30_19_PM.png)

####Tech Stack & Tools:
1. HTML5 & CSS3
2. Angular JS
3. Ionic Framework
4. PhoneGap 
5. Scala & Play Framework
6. Sass
7. Grunt
8. Heroku
9. Git


Fingers crossed we get approved :)

$ open .
```

posts.title: Open Sublime 3 From Terminal
posts.markdown: I [Sublime](http://www.sublimetext.com/3) as sometimes vi just doesn't cut it. Opening sublime up from the Terminal is easy, just setup a sym link. ``` $ ln -s "/Applications/Sublime Text.app/Contents/SharedSupport/bin/subl" /usr/local/bin/sublime ``` then: ``` $ sublime file.name OR $ sublime /my/dir ``` viola!
posts.html:
I Sublime as sometimes vi just doesn't cut it.
Opening sublime up from the Terminal is easy, just setup a sym link. 

$ ln -s "/Applications/Sublime Text.app/Contents/SharedSupport/bin/subl" /usr/local/bin/sublime

then:

$ sublime file.name OR
$ sublime /my/dir

viola!

posts.title: Git Auto-Complete in Terminal
posts.markdown:
Tab completion for Terminal is pretty easy, add the .bash script to your ~ directory.
```
$ curl https://raw.github.com/git/git/master/contrib/completion/git-completion.bash -OL
```
and then updated your profile
```
$ vi ~/.profile
```
with
```
source ~/git-completion.bash
```

and don't forget to make the changes apply to the current terminal session
```
$ source ~/.profile
```
posts.html:
Tab completion for Terminal is pretty easy, add the .bash script to your ~ directory. 

$ curl https://raw.github.com/git/git/master/contrib/completion/git-completion.bash -OL

and then updated your profile 

$ vi ~/.profile

with 

source ~/git-completion.bash

and don't forget to make the changes apply to the current terminal session 

$ source ~/.profile

posts.title: PhoneGap Talk at Girl Geek Sydney
posts.markdown:
Tonight I [gave a talk at Atlassian](https://ggdsyd-feb-2014.eventbrite.com.au) for a Girl Geek Sydney event. My talk was on PhoneGap where I described the She Hacks app that myself and [@rowdyrabbit](https://twitter.com/rowdyrabbit) built together for the upcoming [She Hacks hackathon](http://www.girlgeeksydney.com/she-hacks/). The She Hacks App can be downloaded from: + [Apple App Store](https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/she-hacks/id808697061?mt=8)
+ [Google Play Store](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.girlgeeksydney.shehacks&hl=en)
posts.html:
